prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ratting two people out for cheating on a final exam?
Yesterday, I took a final exam for one of my courses (this is university btw) and I looked up to check the clock to see how much time I had left when I noticed the guy next to me had notecards underneath his test. Moments later, he poked his friend's back, who happened to be sitting in the seat in front of them, and leaned over their shoulder to see their test.

This exam was brutal and if they happened to do well then they could've messed up the curve for the entire class (which is only about 30 students). So I wrote a note on my test saying what was going on and asked my professor if I could go to the restroom. I gave her my test for safekeeping and pointed it out. She nodded and I went to the bathroom (I actually did have to go).

When I came back, she handed me my test where she had written that she'll take care of it. She was watching them for the rest of the class and eventually caught them in the act. She confiscated their tests and took them outside. They did not return.

Now some of my friends are telling me that I did the right thing because they were stupid for trying to cheat on a final in college while some of them are saying that it was wrong of me because school is difficult. Also cheating results in automatic failure in this class.

TLDR: Noticed two people were cheating, told the professor in a ninja manner, and possibly made them failed the class.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

However, sometimes institutions have specific procedures for reporting, like immediately informing the proctor. But in this case, the professor acknowledged the note and acted. 

Another point is the intent. The author's motivation was to prevent cheating, which affects the curve. The cheaters could have unfairly benefited, harming others. The author didn't act out of spite but to maintain fairness. However, some might argue that the author overstepped by not directly confronting the cheaters or using the official method. 

Also, the outcome: the professor handled it, and the cheaters were caught. So the action led to a resolution. The question is whether the method was appropriate. If the university allows students to report misconduct discreetly, then it's okay. But if the protocol is to inform the proctor immediately, then the author's method might not be the best. 

But the professor did respond, so maybe the method worked. The key here is whether the author acted in accordance with institutional policies. Since the scenario doesn't mention any policy violations, and the professor handled it, the action might be justified. 

On the other hand, some might say that the author should not have taken the initiative, but in academic settings, students are often encouraged to report unethical behavior. The automatic failure for cheating is a strict policy, so the author's report led to that, which is fair. 

So considering all that, the author is probably not in the wrong. The answer would be B.
